author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: I confess at these words a shudder passed through me. There was a thrill in the doctor's voice which showed that he was himself deeply moved by that which he told us. Holmes leaned forward in his excitement and his eyes had the hard, dry glitter which shot from them when he was keenly interested.

next.content: "You saw this?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "You saw this?"

next.content: "As clearly as I see you."

next.content: "Excellent! This is a colleague, Watson, after our own heart. But the marks?"

previous.content: "How do you know that?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Excellent! This is a colleague, Watson, after our own heart. But the marks?"

next.content: "He had left his own marks all over that small patch of gravel. I could discern no others."

previous.content: "Because the ash had twice dropped from his cigar."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "He had left his own marks all over that small patch of gravel. I could discern no others."

next.content: Sherlock Holmes struck his hand against his knee with an impatient gesture.

previous.content: "Excellent! This is a colleague, Watson, after our own heart. But the marks?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: Sherlock Holmes struck his hand against his knee with an impatient gesture.

next.content: "If I had only been there!" he cried. "It is evidently a case of extraordinary interest, and one which presented immense opportunities to the scientific expert. That gravel page upon which I might have read so much has been long ere this smudged by the rain and defaced by the clogs of curious peasants.

previous.content: "He had left his own marks all over that small patch of gravel. I could discern no others."

author: By A. Conan Doyle

content: Oh, Dr. Mortimer, Dr. Mortimer, to think that you should not have called me in! You have indeed much to answer for."

next.content: "I could not call you in, Mr. Holmes, without disclosing these facts to the world, and I have already given my reasons for not wishing to do so. Besides, besides—"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "I could not call you in, Mr. Holmes, without disclosing these facts to the world, and I have already given my reasons for not wishing to do so. Besides, besides—"

next.content: "Why do you hesitate?"

previous.content: Oh, Dr. Mortimer, Dr. Mortimer, to think that you should not have called me in! You have indeed much to answer for."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Why do you hesitate?"

next.content: "There is a realm in which the most acute and most experienced of detectives is helpless."

previous.content: "I could not call you in, Mr. Holmes, without disclosing these facts to the world, and I have already given my reasons for not wishing to do so. Besides, besides—"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "There is a realm in which the most acute and most experienced of detectives is helpless."

next.content: "You mean that the thing is supernatural?"

previous.content: "Why do you hesitate?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "You mean that the thing is supernatural?"

next.content: "I did not positively say so."

previous.content: "There is a realm in which the most acute and most experienced of detectives is helpless."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "I did not positively say so."

next.content: "No, but you evidently think it."

previous.content: "You mean that the thing is supernatural?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "No, but you evidently think it."

next.content: "Since the tragedy, Mr. Holmes, there have come to my ears several incidents which are hard to reconcile with the settled order of Nature."

previous.content: "I did not positively say so."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Since the tragedy, Mr. Holmes, there have come to my ears several incidents which are hard to reconcile with the settled order of Nature."

next.content: "For example?"

previous.content: "No, but you evidently think it."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "For example?"

next.content: "I find that before the terrible event occurred several people had seen a creature upon the moor which corresponds with this Baskerville demon, and which could not possibly be any animal known to science. They all agreed that it was a huge creature, luminous, ghastly, and spectral. I have cross-examined these men, one of them a hard-headed countryman, one a farrier, and one a moorland farmer, who all tell the same story of this dreadful apparition, exactly corresponding to the hell-hound of the legend.

previous.content: "Since the tragedy, Mr. Holmes, there have come to my ears several incidents which are hard to reconcile with the settled order of Nature."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "I find that before the terrible event occurred several people had seen a creature upon the moor which corresponds with this Baskerville demon, and which could not possibly be any animal known to science. They all agreed that it was a huge creature, luminous, ghastly, and spectral. I have cross-examined these men, one of them a hard-headed countryman, one a farrier, and one a moorland farmer, who all tell the same story of this dreadful apparition, exactly corresponding to the hell-hound of the legend.

next.content: I assure you that there is a reign of terror in the district, and that it is a hardy man who will cross the moor at night."

previous.content: "For example?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: I assure you that there is a reign of terror in the district, and that it is a hardy man who will cross the moor at night."

next.content: "And you, a trained man of science, believe it to be supernatural?"

previous.content: "I find that before the terrible event occurred several people had seen a creature upon the moor which corresponds with this Baskerville demon, and which could not possibly be any animal known to science. They all agreed that it was a huge creature, luminous, ghastly, and spectral. I have cross-examined these men, one of them a hard-headed countryman, one a farrier, and one a moorland farmer, who all tell the same story of this dreadful apparition, exactly corresponding to the hell-hound of the legend.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "And you, a trained man of science, believe it to be supernatural?"

next.content: "I do not know what to believe."

previous.content: I assure you that there is a reign of terror in the district, and that it is a hardy man who will cross the moor at night."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "I do not know what to believe."

next.content: Holmes shrugged his shoulders. "I have hitherto confined my investigations to this world," said he. "In a modest way I have combated evil, but to take on the Father of Evil himself would, perhaps, be too ambitious a task. Yet you must admit that the footmark is material."

previous.content: "And you, a trained man of science, believe it to be supernatural?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: Holmes shrugged his shoulders. "I have hitherto confined my investigations to this world," said he. "In a modest way I have combated evil, but to take on the Father of Evil himself would, perhaps, be too ambitious a task. Yet you must admit that the footmark is material."

next.content: "The original hound was material enough to tug a man's throat out, and yet he was diabolical as well."

previous.content: "I do not know what to believe."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "The original hound was material enough to tug a man's throat out, and yet he was diabolical as well."

next.content: "I see that you have quite gone over to the supernaturalists. But now, Dr. Mortimer, tell me this. If you hold these views, why have you come to consult me at all? You tell me in the same breath that it is useless to investigate Sir Charles's death, and that you desire me to do it."

previous.content: Holmes shrugged his shoulders. "I have hitherto confined my investigations to this world," said he. "In a modest way I have combated evil, but to take on the Father of Evil himself would, perhaps, be too ambitious a task. Yet you must admit that the footmark is material."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "I see that you have quite gone over to the supernaturalists. But now, Dr. Mortimer, tell me this. If you hold these views, why have you come to consult me at all? You tell me in the same breath that it is useless to investigate Sir Charles's death, and that you desire me to do it."

next.content: "I did not say that I desired you to do it."

previous.content: "The original hound was material enough to tug a man's throat out, and yet he was diabolical as well."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "I did not say that I desired you to do it."

next.content: "Then, how can I assist you?"

previous.content: "I see that you have quite gone over to the supernaturalists. But now, Dr. Mortimer, tell me this. If you hold these views, why have you come to consult me at all? You tell me in the same breath that it is useless to investigate Sir Charles's death, and that you desire me to do it."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Then, how can I assist you?"

next.content: "By advising me as to what I should do with Sir Henry Baskerville, who arrives at Waterloo Station"—Dr. Mortimer looked at his watch—"in exactly one hour and a quarter."

previous.content: "I did not say that I desired you to do it."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "By advising me as to what I should do with Sir Henry Baskerville, who arrives at Waterloo Station"—Dr. Mortimer looked at his watch—"in exactly one hour and a quarter."

next.content: "He being the heir?"

previous.content: "Then, how can I assist you?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "He being the heir?"

next.content: "Yes. On the death of Sir Charles we inquired for this young gentleman and found that he had been farming in Canada. From the accounts which have reached us he is an excellent fellow in every way. I speak now not as a medical man but as a trustee and executor of Sir Charles's will."

previous.content: "By advising me as to what I should do with Sir Henry Baskerville, who arrives at Waterloo Station"—Dr. Mortimer looked at his watch—"in exactly one hour and a quarter."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Yes. On the death of Sir Charles we inquired for this young gentleman and found that he had been farming in Canada. From the accounts which have reached us he is an excellent fellow in every way. I speak now not as a medical man but as a trustee and executor of Sir Charles's will."

next.content: "There is no other claimant, I presume?"

previous.content: "He being the heir?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "There is no other claimant, I presume?"

next.content: "None. The only other kinsman whom we have been able to trace was Rodger Baskerville, the youngest of three brothers of whom poor Sir Charles was the elder. The second brother, who died young, is the father of this lad Henry. The third, Rodger, was the black sheep of the family. He came of the old masterful Baskerville strain and was the very image, they tell me, of the family picture of old Hugo.

previous.content: "Yes. On the death of Sir Charles we inquired for this young gentleman and found that he had been farming in Canada. From the accounts which have reached us he is an excellent fellow in every way. I speak now not as a medical man but as a trustee and executor of Sir Charles's will."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "None. The only other kinsman whom we have been able to trace was Rodger Baskerville, the youngest of three brothers of whom poor Sir Charles was the elder. The second brother, who died young, is the father of this lad Henry. The third, Rodger, was the black sheep of the family. He came of the old masterful Baskerville strain and was the very image, they tell me, of the family picture of old Hugo.

next.content: He made England too hot to hold him, fled to Central America, and died there in 1876 of yellow fever. Henry is the last of the Baskervilles. In one hour and five minutes I meet him at Waterloo Station. I have had a wire that he arrived at Southampton this morning. Now, Mr. Holmes, what would you ad

In one hour and five minutes I meet him at Waterloo Station. I have had a wire that he arrived at Southampton this morning. Now, Mr. Holmes, what would you ad

next.content: vise me to do with him?"

previous.content: "None. The only other kinsman whom we have been able to trace was Rodger Baskerville, the youngest of three brothers of whom poor Sir Charles was the elder. The second brother, who died young, is the father of this lad Henry. The third, Rodger, was the black sheep of the family. He came of the old masterful Baskerville strain and was the very image, they tell me, of the family picture of old Hugo.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: vise me to do with him?"

next.content: "Why should he not go to the home of his fathers?"

previous.content: He made England too hot to hold him, fled to Central America, and died there in 1876 of yellow fever. Henry is the last of the Baskervilles. In one hour and five minutes I meet him at Waterloo Station. I have had a wire that he arrived at Southampton this morning. Now, Mr. Holmes, what would you ad

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Why should he not go to the home of his fathers?"

next.content: "It seems natural, does it not? And yet, consider that every Baskerville who goes there meets with an evil fate. I feel sure that if Sir Charles could have spoken with me before his death he would have warned me against bringing this, the last of the old race, and the heir to great wealth, to that deadly place.

previous.content: vise me to do with him?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "It seems natural, does it not? And yet, consider that every Baskerville who goes there meets with an evil fate. I feel sure that if Sir Charles could have spoken with me before his death he would have warned me against bringing this, the last of the old race, and the heir to great wealth, to that deadly place.

next.content: And yet it cannot be denied that the prosperity of the whole poor, bleak countryside depends upon his presence. All the good work which has been done by Sir Charles will crash to the ground if there is no tenant of the Hall. I fear lest I should be swayed too much by my own obvious interest in the matter, and that is why I bring the case before you and ask for your advice.

previous.content: "Why should he not go to the home of his fathers?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: And yet it cannot be denied that the prosperity of the whole poor, bleak countryside depends upon his presence. All the good work which has been done by Sir Charles will crash to the ground if there is no tenant of the Hall. I fear lest I should be swayed too much by my own obvious interest in the matter, and that is why I bring the case before you and ask for your advice.

previous.content: "It seems natural, does it not? And yet, consider that every Baskerville who goes there meets with an evil fate. I feel sure that if Sir Charles could have spoken with me before his death he would have warned me against bringing this, the last of the old race, and the heir to great wealth, to that deadly place.

next.content: Holmes considered for a little time.

previous.content: And yet it cannot be denied that the prosperity of the whole poor, bleak countryside depends upon his presence. All the good work which has been done by Sir Charles will crash to the ground if there is no tenant of the Hall. I fear lest I should be swayed too much by my own obvious interest in the matter, and that is why I bring the case before you and ask for your advice.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: Holmes considered for a little time.

next.content: "Put into plain words, the matter is this," said he. "In your opinion there is a diabolical agency which makes Dartmoor an unsafe abode for a Baskerville—that is your opinion?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Put into plain words, the matter is this," said he. "In your opinion there is a diabolical agency which makes Dartmoor an unsafe abode for a Baskerville—that is your opinion?"

next.content: "At least I might go the length of saying that there is some evidence that this may be so."

previous.content: Holmes considered for a little time.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "At least I might go the length of saying that there is some evidence that this may be so."

next.content: "Exactly. But surely, if your supernatural theory be correct, it could work the young man evil in London as easily as in Devonshire. A devil with merely local powers like a parish vestry would be too inconceivable a thing."

previous.content: "Put into plain words, the matter is this," said he. "In your opinion there is a diabolical agency which makes Dartmoor an unsafe abode for a Baskerville—that is your opinion?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Exactly. But surely, if your supernatural theory be correct, it could work the young man evil in London as easily as in Devonshire. A devil with merely local powers like a parish vestry would be too inconceivable a thing."

next.content: "You put the matter more flippantly, Mr. Holmes, than you would probably do if you were brought into personal contact with these things. Your advice, then, as I understand it, is that the young man will be as safe in Devonshire as in London. He comes in fifty minutes. What would you recommend?"

previous.content: "At least I might go the length of saying that there is some evidence that this may be so."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "You put the matter more flippantly, Mr. Holmes, than you would probably do if you were brought into personal contact with these things. Your advice, then, as I understand it, is that the young man will be as safe in Devonshire as in London. He comes in fifty minutes. What would you recommend?"

next.content: "I recommend, sir, that you take a cab, call off your spaniel who is scratching at my front door, and proceed to Waterloo to meet Sir Henry Baskerville."

previous.content: "Exactly. But surely, if your supernatural theory be correct, it could work the young man evil in London as easily as in Devonshire. A devil with merely local powers like a parish vestry would be too inconceivable a thing."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "I recommend, sir, that you take a cab, call off your spaniel who is scratching at my front door, and proceed to Waterloo to meet Sir Henry Baskerville."

next.content: "And then?"

previous.content: "You put the matter more flippantly, Mr. Holmes, than you would probably do if you were brought into personal contact with these things. Your advice, then, as I understand it, is that the young man will be as safe in Devonshire as in London. He comes in fifty minutes. What would you recommend?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "And then?"

next.content: "And then you will say nothing to him at all until I have made up my mind about the matter."

previous.content: "I recommend, sir, that you take a cab, call off your spaniel who is scratching at my front door, and proceed to Waterloo to meet Sir Henry Baskerville."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "And then you will say nothing to him at all until I have made up my mind about the matter."

next.content: "How long will it take you to make up your mind?"

previous.content: "And then?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "How long will it take you to make up your mind?"

next.content: "Twenty-four hours. At ten o'clock tomorrow, Dr. Mortimer, I will be much obliged to you if you will call upon me here, and it will be of help to me in my plans for the future if you will bring Sir Henry Baskerville with you."

previous.content: "And then you will say nothing to him at all until I have made up my mind about the matter."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Twenty-four hours. At ten o'clock tomorrow, Dr. Mortimer, I will be much obliged to you if you will call upon me here, and it will be of help to me in my plans for the future if you will bring Sir Henry Baskerville with you."

next.content: "I will do so, Mr. Holmes." He scribbled the appointment on his shirt-cuff and hurried off in his strange, peering, absent-minded fashion. Holmes stopped him at the head of the stair.

previous.content: "How long will it take you to make up your mind?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "I will do so, Mr. Holmes." He scribbled the appointment on his shirt-cuff and hurried off in his strange, peering, absent-minded fashion. Holmes stopped him at the head of the stair.

next.content: "Only one more question, Dr. Mortimer. You say that before Sir Charles Baskerville's death several people saw this apparition upon the moor?"

content: "Only one more question, Dr. Mortimer. You say that before Sir Charles Baskerville's death several people saw this apparition upon the moor?"

next.content: "Three people did."

content: "Did any see it after?"

next.content: "I have not heard of any."

previous.content: "Three people did."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "I have not heard of any."

next.content: "Thank you. Good-morning."

previous.content: "Did any see it after?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Thank you. Good-morning."

next.content: Holmes returned to his seat with that quiet look of inward satisfaction which meant that he had a congenial task before him.

previous.content: "I have not heard of any."

author: By A. Conan Doyle

next.content: "Going out, Watson?"

next.content: "Unless I can help you."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Unless I can help you."

next.content: "No, my dear fellow, it is at the hour of action that I turn to you for aid. But this is splendid, really unique from some points of view. When you pass Bradley's, would you ask him to send up a pound of the strongest shag tobacco? Thank you. It would be as well if you could make it convenient not to return before evening.

When you pass Bradley's, would you ask him to send up a pound of the strongest shag tobacco? Thank you. It would be as well if you could make it convenient not to return before evening.

next.content: Then I should be very glad to compare impressions as to this most interesting problem which has been submitted to us this morning."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: Then I should be very glad to compare impressions as to this most interesting problem which has been submitted to us this morning."

next.content: I knew that seclusion and solitude were very necessary for my friend in those hours of intense mental concentration during which he weighed every particle of evidence, constructed alternative theories, balanced one against the other, and made up his mind as to which points were essential and which immaterial.

previous.content: "No, my dear fellow, it is at the hour of action that I turn to you for aid. But this is splendid, really unique from some points of view. When you pass Bradley's, would you ask him to send up a pound of the strongest shag tobacco? Thank you. It would be as well if you could make it convenient not to return before evening.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: I knew that seclusion and solitude were very necessary for my friend in those hours of intense mental concentration during which he weighed every particle of evidence, constructed alternative theories, balanced one against the other, and made up his mind as to which points were essential and which immaterial.

next.content: I therefore spent the day at my club and did not return to Baker Street until evening. It was nearly nine o'clock when I found myself in the sitting-room once more.

previous.content: Then I should be very glad to compare impressions as to this most interesting problem which has been submitted to us this morning."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: I therefore spent the day at my club and did not return to Baker Street until evening. It was nearly nine o'clock when I found myself in the sitting-room once more.

next.content: My first impression as I opened the door was that a fire had broken out, for the room was so filled with smoke that the light of the lamp upon the table was blurred by it. As I entered, however, my fears were set at rest, for it was the acrid fumes of strong coarse tobacco which took me by the throat and set me coughing.

previous.content: I knew that seclusion and solitude were very necessary for my friend in those hours of intense mental concentration during which he weighed every particle of evidence, constructed alternative theories, balanced one against the other, and made up his mind as to which points were essential and which immaterial.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: My first impression as I opened the door was that a fire had broken out, for the room was so filled with smoke that the light of the lamp upon the table was blurred by it. As I entered, however, my fears were set at rest, for it was the acrid fumes of strong coarse tobacco which took me by the throat and set me coughing.

next.content: Through the haze I had a vague vision of Holmes in his dressing-gown coiled up in an armchair with his black clay pipe between his lips. Several rolls of paper lay around him.

previous.content: I therefore spent the day at my club and did not return to Baker Street until evening. It was nearly nine o'clock when I found myself in the sitting-room once more.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Caught cold, Watson?" said he.

next.content: "No, it's this poisonous atmosphere."

content: "No, it's this poisonous atmosphere."

next.content: "I suppose it is pretty thick, now that you mention it."

previous.content: "Caught cold, Watson?" said he.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "I suppose it is pretty thick, now that you mention it."

next.content: "Thick! It is intolerable."

previous.content: "No, it's this poisonous atmosphere."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Thick! It is intolerable."

next.content: "Open the window, then! You have been at your club all day, I perceive."

previous.content: "I suppose it is pretty thick, now that you mention it."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Open the window, then! You have been at your club all day, I perceive."

next.content: "My dear Holmes!"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "My dear Holmes!"

next.content: "Am I right?"

previous.content: "Open the window, then! You have been at your club all day, I perceive."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Am I right?"

next.content: "Certainly, but how?"

previous.content: "My dear Holmes!"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Certainly, but how?"

next.content: He laughed at my bewildered expression. "There is a delightful freshness about you, Watson, which makes it a pleasure to exercise any small powers which I possess at your expense. A gentleman goes forth on a showery and miry day. He returns immaculate in the evening with the gloss still on his hat and his boots.

previous.content: "Am I right?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: He laughed at my bewildered expression. "There is a delightful freshness about you, Watson, which makes it a pleasure to exercise any small powers which I possess at your expense. A gentleman goes forth on a showery and miry day. He returns immaculate in the evening with the gloss still on his hat and his boots.

next.content: He has been a fixture therefore all day. He is not a man with intimate friends. Where, then, could he have been? Is it not obvious?"

previous.content: "Certainly, but how?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: He has been a fixture therefore all day. He is not a man with intimate friends. Where, then, could he have been? Is it not obvious?"

next.content: "Well, it is rather obvious."

previous.content: He laughed at my bewildered expression. "There is a delightful freshness about you, Watson, which makes it a pleasure to exercise any small powers which I possess at your expense. A gentleman goes forth on a showery and miry day. He returns immaculate in the evening with the gloss still on his hat and his boots.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Well, it is rather obvious."

next.content: "The world is full of obvious things which nobody by any chance ever observes. Where do you think that I have been?"

previous.content: He has been a fixture therefore all day. He is not a man with intimate friends. Where, then, could he have been? Is it not obvious?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "The world is full of obvious things which nobody by any chance ever observes. Where do you think that I have been?"

next.content: "A fixture also."

previous.content: "Well, it is rather obvious."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "A fixture also."

next.content: "On the contrary, I have been to Devonshire."

previous.content: "The world is full of obvious things which nobody by any chance ever observes. Where do you think that I have been?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "On the contrary, I have been to Devonshire."

next.content: "In spirit?"

previous.content: "A fixture also."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "In spirit?"

next.content: "Exactly. My body has remained in this armchair and has, I regret to observe, consumed in my absence two large pots of coffee and an incredible amount of tobacco. After you left I sent down to Stamford's for the Ordnance map of this portion of the moor, and my spirit has hovered over it all day. I flatter myself that I could find my way about.

previous.content: "On the contrary, I have been to Devonshire."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Exactly. My body has remained in this armchair and has, I regret to observe, consumed in my absence two large pots of coffee and an incredible amount of tobacco. After you left I sent down to Stamford's for the Ordnance map of this portion of the moor, and my spirit has hovered over it all day. I flatter myself that I could find my way about.

next.content: "A large-scale map, I presume?"

After you left I sent down to Stamford's for the Ordnance map of this portion of the moor, and my spirit has hovered over it all day. I flatter myself that I could find my way about.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "A large-scale map, I presume?"

next.content: "Very large."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Very large."

next.content: He unrolled one section and held it over his knee. "Here you have the particular district which concerns us. That is Baskerville Hall in the middle."

previous.content: "A large-scale map, I presume?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: He unrolled one section and held it over his knee. "Here you have the particular district which concerns us. That is Baskerville Hall in the middle."

next.content: "With a wood round it?"

previous.content: "Very large."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "With a wood round it?"

next.content: "Exactly. I fancy the yew alley, though not marked under that name, must stretch along this line, with the moor, as you perceive, upon the right of it. This small clump of buildings here is the hamlet of Grimpen, where our friend Dr. Mortimer has his headquarters. Within a radius of five miles there are, as you see, only a very few scattered dwellings.

previous.content: He unrolled one section and held it over his knee. "Here you have the particular district which concerns us. That is Baskerville Hall in the middle."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Exactly. I fancy the yew alley, though not marked under that name, must stretch along this line, with the moor, as you perceive, upon the right of it. This small clump of buildings here is the hamlet of Grimpen, where our friend Dr. Mortimer has his headquarters. Within a radius of five miles there are, as you see, only a very few scattered dwellings.

next.content: Here is Lafter Hall, which was mentioned in the narrative. There is a house indicated here which may be the residence of the naturalist—Stapleton, if I remember right, was his name. Here are two moorland farmhouses, High Tor and Foulmire. Then fourteen miles away the great convict prison of Princetown.

previous.content: "With a wood round it?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: Here is Lafter Hall, which was mentioned in the narrative. There is a house indicated here which may be the residence of the naturalist—Stapleton, if I remember right, was his name. Here are two moorland farmhouses, High Tor and Foulmire. Then fourteen miles away the great convict prison of Princetown.

next.content: Between and around these scattered points extends the desolate, lifeless moor. This, then, is the stage upon which tragedy has been played, and upon which we may help to play it again."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "It must be a wild place."

next.content: "Yes, the setting is a worthy one. If the devil did desire to have a hand in the affairs of men—"

previous.content: Between and around these scattered points extends the desolate, lifeless moor. This, then, is the stage upon which tragedy has been played, and upon which we may help to play it again."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Yes, the setting is a worthy one. If the devil did desire to have a hand in the affairs of men—"

next.content: "Then you are yourself inclining to the supernatural explanation."

previous.content: "It must be a wild place."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Then you are yourself inclining to the supernatural explanation."

next.content: "The devil's agents may be of flesh and blood, may they not? There are two questions waiting for us at the outset. The one is whether any crime has been committed at all; the second is, what is the crime and how was it committed? Of course, if Dr. Mortimer's surmise should be correct, and we are dealing with forces outside the ordinary laws of Nature, there is an end of our investigation.

previous.content: "Yes, the setting is a worthy one. If the devil did desire to have a hand in the affairs of men—"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "The devil's agents may be of flesh and blood, may they not? There are two questions waiting for us at the outset. The one is whether any crime has been committed at all; the second is, what is the crime and how was it committed? Of course, if Dr. Mortimer's surmise should be correct, and we are dealing with forces outside the ordinary laws of Nature, there is an end of our investigation.

next.content: But we are bound to exhaust all other hypotheses before falling back upon this one. I think we'll shut that window again, if you don't mind. It is a singular thing, but I find that a concentrated atmosphere helps a concentration of thought. I have not pushed it to the length of getting into a box to think, but that is the logical outcome of my convictions.

previous.content: "Then you are yourself inclining to the supernatural explanation."

content: "What do you make of it?"

next.content: "It is very bewildering."

previous.content: "Yes, I have thought a good deal of it in the course of the day."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "It is very bewildering."

next.content: "It has certainly a character of its own. There are points of distinction about it. That change in the footprints, for example. What do you make of that?"

previous.content: "What do you make of it?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "It has certainly a character of its own. There are points of distinction about it. That change in the footprints, for example. What do you make of that?"

next.content: "Mortimer said that the man had walked on tiptoe down that portion of the alley."

previous.content: "It is very bewildering."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Mortimer said that the man had walked on tiptoe down that portion of the alley."

next.content: "He only repeated what some fool had said at the inquest. Why should a man walk on tiptoe down the alley?"

previous.content: "It has certainly a character of its own. There are points of distinction about it. That change in the footprints, for example. What do you make of that?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "He only repeated what some fool had said at the inquest. Why should a man walk on tiptoe down the alley?"

next.content: "What then?"

previous.content: "Mortimer said that the man had walked on tiptoe down that portion of the alley."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "What then?"

next.content: "He was running, Watson—running desperately, running for his life, running until he burst his heart—and fell dead upon his face."

previous.content: "He only repeated what some fool had said at the inquest. Why should a man walk on tiptoe down the alley?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "He was running, Watson—running desperately, running for his life, running until he burst his heart—and fell dead upon his face."

next.content: "Running from what?"

previous.content: "What then?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Running from what?"

next.content: "There lies our problem. There are indications that the man was crazed with fear before ever he began to run."

previous.content: "He was running, Watson—running desperately, running for his life, running until he burst his heart—and fell dead upon his face."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "There lies our problem. There are indications that the man was crazed with fear before ever he began to run."

next.content: "How can you say that?"

previous.content: "Running from what?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "How can you say that?"

next.content: "I am presuming that the cause of his fears came to him across the moor. If that were so, and it seems most probable, only a man who had lost his wits would have run from the house instead of towards it. If the gipsy's evidence may be taken as true, he ran with cries for help in the direction where help was least likely to be.

previous.content: "There lies our problem. There are indications that the man was crazed with fear before ever he began to run."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "I am presuming that the cause of his fears came to him across the moor. If the gipsy's evidence may be taken as true, he ran with cries for help in the direction where help was least likely to be.

next.content: Then, again, whom was he waiting for that night, and why was he waiting for him in the yew alley rather than in his own house?"

previous.content: "How can you say that?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: Then, again, whom was he waiting for that night, and why was he waiting for him in the yew alley rather than in his own house?"

next.content: "You think that he was waiting for someone?"

content: "You think that he was waiting for someone?"

next.content: "The man was elderly and infirm. We can understand his taking an evening stroll, but the ground was damp and the night inclement. Is it natural that he should stand for five or ten minutes, as Dr. Mortimer, with more practical sense than I should have given him credit for, deduced from the cigar ash

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "But he went out every evening."

next.content: "I think it unlikely that he waited at the moor-gate every evening. On the contrary, the evidence is that he avoided the moor. That night he waited there. It was the night before he made his departure for London. The thing takes shape, Watson. It becomes coherent. Might I ask you to hand me my violin, and we will postpone all further thought upon this business until we have had the advantage of meeting Dr.
